name: diphenyl(9H-xanthen-9-yl)phosphane oxide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2796

name: diphenyl(9H-xanthen-9-yl)phosphane oxide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2796
Reason: The compound diphenyl(9H-xanthen-9-yl)phosphane oxide is composed of a xanthene ring system combined with two additional phenyl groups and a phosphane oxide group. The basic unit of xanthene has a melting point of approximately 110°C. The incorporation of two phenyl groups is expected to increase the melting point due to the increase in molecular complexity and pi-pi interactions, which we can approximate at +20°C per phenyl group. The phosphane oxide group introduces polarity and potential for hydrogen bonding, further increasing the melting point, which can be approximated at +30°C. The overall increase by adding these functionalities would be (20 * 2) + 30 = +70°C to the basic xanthene unit.

name: diphenyl(9H-xanthen-9-yl)phosphane oxide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2796
Reason: Diphenyl(9H-xanthen-9-yl)phosphane oxide features a xanthene core structure which has a base melting point of approximately 110°C. Adding two phenyl groups to the xanthene core will increase the molecular weight and the potential for additional π-π interactions, contributing an estimated +10°C per phenyl group. The phosphane oxide group not only increases molecular weight but also introduces polar and potential hydrogen bonding interactions, which is likely to significantly raise the melting point. Conservatively, this could be estimated to contribute an additional +30°C, taking into account the significant impact on both molecular weight and intermolecular forces. Combining these effects yields a calculation of +10°C for each phenyl group and +30°C for the phosphane oxide group for a total of +50°C to the basic xanthene unit.
